questions.text: Do you have written information security policies that is reviewed and approved annually?

options.option: No formal information security policies exist
options.risk: Without documented policies, there is no formal direction or accountability for security practices, increasing non-compliance.

options.option: Draft policies exist but not formally approved
options.risk: Unapproved drafts are unenforceable and may conflict with legal or contractual obligations.

options.option: Approved policies exist; last review was over 24 months ago
options.risk: Outdated policies reference obsolete controls and miss emerging threats.

options.option: Approved policies exist; last review within the last 12–24 months
options.risk: Infrequent reviews can miss organizational or regulatory changes, causing drift.

options.option: Approved policies exist; reviewed and approved within the last 12 months
options.risk: Annual approval strengthens governance but may lack traceable integrity without versioning.

options.option: Approved policies exist; reviewed within the last 12 months and version control is maintained
options.risk: Version control improves auditability; unclear ownership can delay critical updates.

options.option: Approved policies exist; reviewed within the last 12 months with documented evidence and senior management sign-off
options.risk: Strong governance minimizes policy risk; adherence still requires verification.

questions.text: Are policies and standards communicated to all employees and contractors?

options.option: No formal information security policies exist
options.risk: Without documented policies, there is no formal direction or accountability for security practices, increasing non-compliance.

options.option: Approved policies exist; reviewed within the last 12 months and version control is maintained
options.risk: Version control improves auditability; unclear ownership can delay critical updates.

options.option: Draft policies exist but not formally approved
options.risk: Unapproved drafts are unenforceable and may conflict with legal or contractual obligations.

options.option: Approved policies exist; reviewed within the last 12 months with documented evidence and senior management sign-off
options.risk: Strong governance minimizes policy risk; adherence still requires verification.

options.option: Approved policies exist; last review was over 24 months ago
options.risk: Outdated policies reference obsolete controls and miss emerging threats.

options.option: Approved policies exist; last review within the last 12–24 months
options.risk: Infrequent reviews can miss organizational or regulatory changes, causing drift.

options.option: Approved policies exist; reviewed and approved within the last 12 months
options.risk: Annual approval strengthens governance but may lack traceable integrity without versioning.

questions.text: Do you maintain an inventory of information systems, applications, and assets?

options.option: No asset inventory exists
options.risk: Without an inventory, unknown assets cannot be secured, patched, or monitored.

options.option: Manual, ad hoc inventory
options.risk: Manual lists are error-prone and quickly outdated.

options.option: Partial inventory not covering all systems or apps
options.risk: Partial visibility leaves untracked assets unmanaged and exploitable.

options.option: Centralized inventory for endpoints, servers, and major applications
options.risk: Centralization improves oversight; stale data still hinders response and lifecycle tasks.

options.option: Automated, reconciled inventory across endpoints, servers, network, cloud, and SaaS
options.risk: Automation minimizes unknown assets; ownership must still be enforced.

questions.text: Is there a designated individual or committee accountable for the security program?

options.option: No individual or committee is accountable for the security program
options.risk: Without an accountable owner, risks go unmanaged and response is uncoordinated.

options.option: Responsibilities are informally assigned but not documented
options.risk: Informal assignments create ambiguity and gaps in critical tasks.

options.option: A designated individual is accountable but lacks authority or resources
options.risk: Insufficient authority or resources undermines enforcement of controls.

options.option: A security leader (e.g., CISO/vCISO) oversees the program with defined responsibilities
options.risk: A defined leader improves accountability; cross-functional gaps may remain.

options.option: A leader and governance committee manage the program with charters, KPIs, and executive oversight
options.risk: Governance structures reduce risk; sponsorship and funding must be sustained.

questions.text: Do you maintain a risk register that tracks identified risks and mitigation actions?

options.option: No risk register maintained
options.risk: Without a register, risks are unmanaged and forgotten.

options.option: Informal tracking without owners or due dates
options.risk: Informal tracking loses accountability and timeliness.

options.option: Register exists with owners/status but irregular updates
options.risk: Irregular updates obscure current exposure and progress.

options.option: Maintained register with owners, due dates, treatment plans, and review cadence
options.risk: Maintained registers improve transparency; integration may still be weak.

options.option: Register integrated with governance reporting driving prioritization and funding
options.risk: Governance-linked registers drive remediation; acceptance criteria must be clear.

questions.text: Is MFA used in your organization?

options.option: MFA is not enforced for privileged or remote access
options.risk: Without MFA, credential compromise can lead to immediate unauthorized access.

options.option: MFA is enforced for remote access only
options.risk: Remote-only MFA leaves privileged lateral movement exposed internally.

options.option: MFA is enforced for privileged accounts and remote access
options.risk: MFA for privileged and remote reduces takeover risk; high-risk apps may remain exposed.

options.option: MFA is enforced for all privileged/remote access and high-risk apps with conditional access
options.risk: Broad MFA with conditional access reduces compromise risk; exceptions must be managed.

questions.text: Are accounts provisioned and deprovisioned according to a documented workflow?

options.option: Accounts are created/removed without a documented workflow
options.risk: Undocumented processes cause orphaned accounts and excessive access.

options.option: Documented workflow exists but is inconsistently followed
options.risk: Inconsistent execution delays removals and leaves stale access.

options.option: Documented workflow with approvals and checklists for provisioning/deprovisioning
options.risk: Documented workflows reduce errors; manual steps can lag.

options.option: Automated workflow via HRIS/IdP integration with logged access changes
options.risk: Automation shrinks exposure windows and improves audit trails; failures must be monitored.

questions.text: Do you review user access rights at least annually?

options.option: User access rights are not reviewed periodically
options.risk: Without reviews, excessive or stale access persists unnoticed.

options.option: Access reviews ad hoc or annually for key systems
options.risk: Limited reviews miss toxic combinations and least-privilege gaps.

options.option: Quarterly reviews for key systems with remediation tracking
options.risk: Quarterly reviews reduce privilege creep; scope gaps may remain.

options.option: Quarterly reviews for all systems tied to role changes and regulated needs
options.risk: Comprehensive reviews limit abuse risk; sustained effort required.

questions.text: Are privileged sessions logged and monitored?

options.option: Privileged sessions are not logged or monitored
options.risk: Lack of monitoring hides misuse and lateral movement.

options.option: Privileged sessions are logged but not reviewed
options.risk: Unreviewed logs provide weak deterrence and delayed detection.

options.option: Logs are reviewed with alerts
options.risk: Reviews with alerts improve detection; fast attacks may still evade.

options.option: Real-time monitoring and session recording for critical systems
options.risk: Real-time monitoring enhances response and forensics; storage/privacy must be managed.

questions.text: Are endpoints protected with centrally managed anti-malware/EDR?

options.option: Legacy AV on some endpoints
options.risk: Legacy AV misses modern techniques, allowing dwell time and exfiltration.

options.option: EDR on all workstations
options.risk: Workstation EDR reduces user-driven compromise; servers may remain targets.

options.option: EDR on all endpoints including servers with MDR/SOC monitoring
options.risk: Comprehensive EDR with MDR cuts detection time; tuning gaps may persist.

options.option: No centrally managed anti-malware/EDR
options.risk: Without endpoint protection, malware and ransomware can spread rapidly.

questions.text: Are systems regularly patched and updated according to a defined schedule?

options.option: Patching is ad hoc with no defined SLAs
options.risk: Ad hoc patching leaves known vulnerabilities exploitable.

options.option: Monthly for workstations; servers ad hoc
options.risk: Inconsistent cadence creates uneven exposure across systems.

options.option: Defined SLAs for all systems with maintenance windows
options.risk: SLAs reduce exposure windows; exceptions must be tracked.

options.option: Risk-based patching with rapid remediation and compliance reporting
options.risk: Risk-based patching minimizes high-impact exposure; disruptions must be managed.

questions.text: Do you use secure baseline configurations for servers, endpoints, and cloud environments?

options.option: No secure baseline configurations used
options.risk: Without baselines, configurations are inconsistent and insecure.

options.option: Baselines for a subset of systems
options.risk: Partial baselines leave exploitable gaps.

options.option: Baselines for servers and endpoints with periodic review
options.risk: Periodic reviews improve consistency; enforcement gaps allow drift.

options.option: Baselines for servers, endpoints, and cloud with enforced compliance and drift remediation
options.risk: Enforced baselines limit misconfigurations; exceptions must be justified.

questions.text: Are backups encrypted and stored in a separate, secured environment?

options.option: Backups are not encrypted or are stored with production
options.risk: Unencrypted or co-resident backups enable data theft and ransomware impact.

options.option: Backups are encrypted but stored within same security domain
options.risk: Same-domain storage risks simultaneous compromise.

options.option: Backups are encrypted and stored in a separate secured environment
options.risk: Separate, encrypted storage improves resilience; admin path risks remain.

options.option: Backups are encrypted, immutable/offline, with segregated access
options.risk: Immutable/offline backups resist ransomware; restores must be tested.

questions.text: Do you log and monitor security events from critical systems?

options.option: Security event logs are not centralized
options.risk: Decentralized logs impede detection and forensics.

options.option: Logs centralized for a subset of sources
options.risk: Partial centralization leaves blind spots.

options.option: Logs centralized broadly with parsing and normalization
options.risk: Broad, normalized logging improves detection; storage/cost must be managed.

questions.text: Are alerts from detection tools actively triaged and investigated?

options.option: No defined thresholds or alerts for suspicious activity
options.risk: Without alerts, suspicious activity goes unnoticed until damage occurs.

options.option: Basic alerts for common events
options.risk: Basic alerts catch common issues but can cause noise and fatigue.

options.option: Risk-based alerts tuned with runbooks and escalation
options.risk: Tuned, risk-based alerts speed response; maintenance is required to avoid drift.

questions.text: Is there a documented Incident Response Plan (IRP)?

options.option: No documented Incident Response Plan (IRP)
options.risk: Without an IRP, response is ad hoc, slow, and error-prone.

options.option: Draft IRP not approved or maintained
options.risk: Unapproved or stale IRP undermines coordination during crises.

options.option: Approved IRP reviewed at least annually
options.risk: Reviewed IRP improves readiness; effectiveness depends on training and exercises.

questions.text: Are incident response exercises (tabletop or live) conducted annually?

options.option: No incident response exercises conducted
options.risk: Without exercises, teams are unprepared and roles unclear.

options.option: Tabletop exercises conducted less than annually
options.risk: Infrequent exercises allow process drift and skill atrophy.

options.option: Annual incident response exercises with tracked action items
options.risk: Annual exercises with tracked actions improve readiness; live-play may be needed.

questions.text: Do employees receive security awareness training at least annually?

options.option: No security awareness training provided
options.risk: Lack of training increases human error and social engineering risk.

options.option: Training less than annually or only at onboarding
options.risk: Infrequent training leaves users unaware of evolving threats.

options.option: Annual training with completion tracking
options.risk: Annual tracked training raises awareness; reinforcement may still be needed.

questions.text: Do you assess vendor security controls before onboarding?

options.option: No regular reporting to executive leadership or board
options.risk: Lack of reporting limits oversight and deprioritizes security investment.

options.option: Informal updates or post-incident reporting only
options.risk: Informal updates hinder accountability and timely decisions.

options.option: Periodic activity-focused reports (not risk/outcomes)
options.risk: Activity-heavy reports obscure true risk and priorities.

options.option: Regular reporting of key risks, metrics, and remediation status
options.risk: Risk/metric-focused reporting enables decisions; actions still must be driven.

options.option: Reporting aligned to risk appetite with explicit decision requests
options.risk: Risk appetite alignment accelerates resourcing; deferral still creates exposure.

questions.text: Do contracts include data protection and confidentiality obligations?

options.option: Contracts lack data protection or confidentiality obligations
options.risk: Weak contracts reduce leverage to enforce security with vendors.

options.option: Contracts include basic confidentiality clauses
options.risk: Basic confidentiality lacks concrete security requirements.

options.option: Contracts include data protection, breach notification, and security control obligations aligned to risk
options.risk: Risk-aligned clauses improve enforceability; monitoring remains necessary.
